info.name: MagicMirror Remote Control API
info.description:
## Introduction

The MMM-Remote-Control Module for MagicMirror² implements a RESTful(-ish) API to control the Magic Mirror using the existing functionality built-in to MMM-Remote-Control, as well as the notifications commands built into most modules.  In addition, the API creates a basic framework which allows for each module to expand or customize their own API by a simple notificiation.

This expansion was developed by [shbatm](https://github.com/shbatm) using [juzim's MMM-Api](https://github.com/juzim/MMM-Api) and of-course, [jopyth's MMM-Remote-Control](https://github.com/jopyth/MMM-Remote-Control).

## Overview

This extension exposes the `/api` URL from your MagicMirror² installation. Just like using the regular MMM-Remote-Control module, make sure your configuration listens on more than just `localhost`.

All URLs will be of the form: `http://magicmirrorip:8080/api/{your command}` and depending on the command, either `GET` or `POST` methods are accepted.

### Basic examples for showing an Alert on the screen

```bash
$ curl -X GET http://magicmirrorip:8080/api/module/alert/showalert?message=Hello&timer=2000
```

```bash
$ curl -X POST http://magicmirrorip:8080/api/module/alert/showalert \
  -H 'content-type: application/json' \
  -d '{ 
    "title": "Hello World!", 
    "message": "Alert Successfully Shown!", 
    "timer": 2000
    }'
```

## Authentication

Providing an API key is recommended; however, remains optional. If you wish to use an API key to authenticate, add an `apiKey:` option to the config section for this module.

If you ran the `installer.sh` script when you installed the module, a non-canoical UUID is generated for you to use; you can use this unique code, or use any string you wish.

### Example Config Section
```js
{
    module: 'MMM-Remote-Control'
    config: {
        apiKey: 'bc2e979db92f4741afad01d5d18eb8e2'
    }
},
```

### Passing your API key

See the `GET /api/test` section below and use the examples drop down to view various different ways to pass the  API Key. 

***For convenience, the remainder of the examples omit the API Key***

## Common Errors

### Not Connected To Mirror

Some API calls require a Front End (browser) open so the `node_helpers` can be connected. For example, if you run in `serveronly` mode and connect to your Mirror through a web browser--if you do not open the web browser (or refresh the page on a restart) before making an API call, you may get the following response:

```json
{
    "success": false,
    "message": "Not initialized, have you opened or refreshed your browser since the last time you started MagicMirror?"
}
```

Open the web browser (or refresh the page) and try your query again.

# Methods

request.description:
Test the API to make sure it's working.

**Authentication:** See the drop down list in this method's examples to view different ways to pass the API Key.

            }
        }

        "modules": "modules",
        "vendor": "vendor"
    }

Boolean (true or false) value to set the User Presence variable and send a notification to other modules. 
If no value is passed, the current User Presence state is returned, if known.

request.description: Get or Set the USER_PRESENCE status. If no `:value` is sent (just /api/userpresence is called), it will return the USER_PRESENCE state if known.  If `true` or `false` is sent (e.g. /api/userpresence/true), a `"USER_PRESENCE"` notification will be sent to all modules.

variable.description: Return details about a particular module.  Can be a Module Name or Unique Identifier.

request.description: List of all modules currently active.

variable.description: Return details about a particular module.  Can be a Module Name or Unique Identifier.

Module to act upon.  Can be a Module Name or Unique Identifier (e.g. `module_3_clock`).

To SHOW/HIDE/TOGGLE all modules, send "all" as :moduleName

Action to take.  Valid options are "show", "hide", "toggle": or "force" to force a module to be shown if it has a lockstring from another module.
"defaults" will return the default configuration for a given module.

request.description:
# External API requests. **There is a difference between `/api/module` and `/api/modules`** 1. `module` is for the External API (control of another module). 2. `modules` is part of the internal Remote Control system functions. As discussed in the [API README](https://github.com/shbatm/MMM-Remote-Control/tree/wip_api/API), these methods are guessed based on your currently installed modules. To see what actions are available on your particular installation: | Method | URL | Description | | ------ | --- | ------- | | GET | /api/module | Return a list of all external API actions registered. | GET | /api/module/:moduleName | Returns registered API actions for a given module
`:moduleName`: Name or Identifier for an installed & activated module. | GET | /api/module/:moduleName/:action/:p?a=b&c=d | Sends a notification `:action` to the module `:moduleName` with a payload `{ param: p, a: b, c: d }` *NOTE:* Just because an action appears in this list, does not necessarily mean it is valid and the related module will do what you want. Consult each modules' README for details on what notifications can be used and how.

variable.description: Name or Identifier of the Module.
Action name

variable.description: Module Name or Identifier upon which to act.
*Optional* Action to send. If no action is sent, the module's available actions are returned.

request.description:
# Generic Notification Requests

Swiss army knife of the API (and MagicMirror in general) -- If you just want a simple way to send a module notification, this is it.  Payload is treated the same as `/api/module/:moduleName/:action` commands (because it is pretty much the same thing, just without any validation of if a module will recognize the notification).

header.description: This header is required for any POST method.

variable.description: Notification text to send. Payload sent in body.

request.description: `POST` version of the Notification API, more convenient for sending complex payloads via the post body.

header.description: This header is required for any POST method.

variable.description: Module Name or Identifier upon which to act.

header.description: This header is required for any POST method.

query.description: Optional: (Delay ID) Some string to identify your timer, in case you want to cancel it later.
Optional: Abort an existing timer. If you want to cancel a long running timer, pass it again with the same DID and abort=true.

variable.description: Notification text to send. Payload sent in body.
Send "/delay" to delay an action

request.description:
On the following routes, you can add a `/delay` to the end of the URL to delay the action until some time in the future.  The default is 10s, but this can be set in the query string or POST body.

Available for:
- /api/refresh
- /api/shutdown
- /api/reboot
- /api/restart
- /api/monitor/:action
- /api/notification/:notification
- /api/modules/:moduleName/:action
- /api/module/:moduleName/:action

Active timers can be viewed by calling `GET /api/timers`

header.description: This header is required for any POST method.

query.description: Optional: (Delay ID) Some string to identify your timer, in case you want to cancel it later.
Optional: Abort an existing timer. If you want to cancel a long running timer, pass it again with the same DID and abort=true.

variable.description: Notification text to send. Payload sent in body.
Send "/delay" to delay an action
